value.text:
😌🙂‍↕️ ESTOU CIENTE E QUERO CONTINUAR

💵 Moeda dos Brics afetaria economia dos EUA, disse Frank-Jürgen Richter, ex-diretor do Fórum Econômico Mundial. Ele afirmou à CNN que, se China e Índia superarem diferenças e criarem uma moeda comum, o impacto será “um grande choque” pro dólar e EUA.

images.alt:
Foto mostra três cédulas-fantasia que representam uma moeda fictícia dos BRICS (bloco formado por Brasil, Rússia, Índia, China e África do Sul). As notas têm os valores de 50, 100 e 200, e são ricamente ilustradas com elementos simbólicos dos países-membros. O destaque visual está no centro de cada cédula, onde aparece um círculo multicolorido formado pelas bandeiras dos cinco países, com uma moeda dourada ao centro contendo inscrições em vários alfabetos (cirílico, latino e outros). Ao redor, há animais e monumentos representativos — como pavões, gruas e prédios icônicos — além de inscrições como “Российская Федерация” (Federação Russa).

As cédulas estão sendo seguradas por uma mão com luva branca, sugerindo que são itens de coleção ou amostra de propaganda. O fundo mostra um ambiente de biblioteca ou gabinete com estantes de livros e iluminação quente. Essas notas não têm valor legal, mas fazem parte de um material promocional ou conceitual ligado à ideia de criação de uma moeda própria dos BRICS

record.text:
北アイルランド対ドイツ戦、29年ぶりの好結果を目指す厳しい戦い - AIサッカーまとめ

▼詳細はこちら

external.description:
ベルファストのウィンザー・パークで行われる北アイルランド対ドイツの試合に関するライブ中継が行われます。両チームは開幕から3試合で2勝ずつ、6ポイントを獲得しており、ドイツは得失点差で首位に立っています。北アイルランドにとって、この試合で引き分けを取ることが良い結果となるでしょう。実際、北アイルランドは1998年のワールドカップ予選以来、ドイツとの試合で29年ぶりに勝ち点を獲得しています。

ドイツの監督ユリアン・ナーゲルスマンは、9月の試合後に北アイルランドに対するコメントについて誤解を招いたことを謝罪しました。当時、北アイルランドのプレースタイルに「長いボールを多く使う」と言及しましたが、ナーゲルスマンはそのコメントを訂正し、「彼らはそのスタイルを非常に上手くやっている」と強調。北アイルランドのプレースタイルに対する敬意を示し、誤解を招いたことに対して謝罪の意を表しました。
external.title: 北アイルランド対ドイツ戦、29年ぶりの好結果を目指す厳しい戦い - AIサッカーまとめ

record.text:
アンチェロッティ監督、ブラジル代表の未来を語る！日本戦前の会見で明かした戦略と試験 - AIサッカーまとめ

▼詳細はこちら

external.description:
ブラジル代表のカルロ・アンチェロッティ監督（66）は、13日に東京スタジアムで行われる日本代表戦に向けて会見を行った。アンチェロッティ監督は、ブラジル代表の強さを再確認した韓国戦での5-0勝利を振り返り、「美しいサッカー」は個人技だけでなく、組織的な美しさが重要だと語った。チーム作りについては、最初から11人を固定せず、複数のプレースタイルやシステムを試し、最適な戦術を模索すると述べた。

また、守備意識を重視し、バランスの取れたチーム作りを進めている。日本戦も選手を試す場として位置づけ、最終的なメンバーを決定するために、今後も実験を続ける方針を示した。ネイマールについては、コンディションが良ければ代表チームに問題なくフィットすると語り、W杯優勝を目指す決意を新たにした。

アンチェロッティ監督は、2002年のW杯以来の優勝を目指し、他国出身の監督として初めてブラジル代表を頂点に導くことを誓った。
external.title: アンチェロッティ監督、ブラジル代表の未来を語る！日本戦前の会見で明かした戦略と試験 - AIサッカーまとめ

record.text:
5️⃣ In short: An AI Engineer’s job is to make AI useful.

And whether you love or hate the title, it’s here to stay.

AI Engineering is what separates “playing with prompts” from building production AI.

4️⃣ So what do AI Engineers actually build?

Internal tools, customer-facing features, integrations with LLM APIs and context systems, chat interfaces, and automation pipelines.

They spend their time on glue code, orchestration, and context management.

3️⃣ AI is no longer a crutch.

Back in 2023, using AI tools in your workflow was “cheating.”

If you leaned on a copilot too much, you weren’t a “real engineer.”

Fast-forward to 2025: using AI (or at least exploring it) seems to be table stakes.

My go to prompt is usually something like

I just use copilot with Claude 3.7 thinking, it seems to give the best results

record.text:
リィルの絶望が、一瞬の隙を生む。ライツはその刹那、己の中にうごめく感情の濁流をイメージし、外界へと言い放った。

「『永劫潰えぬ破滅の水源』よ」

ライツが杖を突き出す。その先端に、黒い流れが渦を巻く。ごうごうと、音をたてたそれは周囲の空気ごと湿らせていく。

value.text:
信じていた水に裏切られ、リィルは濁流に呑まれる。
そして夜天のライツが放つのは、神話の弓か、それとも破滅の矢か――。
#小説 #創作 #夜天のライツ

record.text:
Karpathy: nanochat

A small training+inference pipeline for  creating your own LLM from scratch 

$100 will get you a somewhat functional model

$1000 is more coherent & solves math

detailed walkthrough: github.com/karpathy/nan...

repo: github.com/karpathy/nan...

images.alt:
Andrej Karpathy & @karpathy
X.com
Excited to release new repo: nanochat! (it's among the most unhinged I've written).
Unlike my earlier similar repo nanoGPT which only covered pretraining, nanochat is a minimal, from scratch, full-stack training/inference pipeline of a simple ChatGPT clone in a single, dependency-minimal codebase. You boot up a cloud GPU box, run a single script and in as little as 4 hours later you can talk to your own LLM in a ChatGPT-like web Ul.
It weighs ~8,000 lines of imo quite clean code to:
- Train the tokenizer using a new Rust implementation
- Pretrain a Transformer LLM on FineWeb, evaluate CORE score across a number of metrics
- Midtrain on user-assistant conversations from SmolTalk, multiple choice questions, tool use.
- SFT, evaluate the chat model on world knowledge multiple choice (ARC-E/C, MMLU), math (GSM8K), code (HumanEval)
- RL the model optionally on GSM8K with
IPDDOI

- RL the model optionally on GSM8K with
"GRPO"
- Efficient inference the model in an Engine with
KV cache, simple prefill/ decode, tool use (Python interpreter in a lightweight sandbox), talk to it over CLI or ChatGPT-like WebUl.
- Write a single markdown report card, summarizing and gamifying the whole thing.
Even for as low as ~$100 in cost (~4 hours on an
8XH100 node), you can train a little ChatGPT clone that you can kind of talk to, and which can write stories/poems, answer simple questions.
About ~12 hours surpasses GPT-2 CORE metric.
As you further scale up towards ~$1000 (~41.6 hours of training), it quickly becomes a lot more coherent and can solve simple math/code problems and take multiple choice tests. E.g. a depth 30 model trained for 24 hours (this is about equal to FLOPs of GPT-3 Small 125M and 1/1000th of GPT-3) gets into 40s on MMLU and
70s on ARC-Easy, 20s on GSM8K, etc.
My goal is to get the full "strong baseline" stack into one cohesive, minimal, readable, hackable, maximally forkable repo. nanochat will be the capstone project of LLM101n (which is still being developed). I think it also has potential to grow

developed). I think it also has potential to grow into a research harness, or a benchmark, similar to nanoGPT before it. It is by no means finished, tuned or optimized (actually I think there's likely quite a bit of low-hanging fruit), but I think it's at a place where the overall skeleton is ok enough that it can go up on GitHub where all the parts of it can be improved.
Link to repo and a detailed walkthrough of the nanochat speedrun is in the reply.
nanochat

record.text:
No technology every popped into total existence from zero, and nothing vanishes into total non-existence either. 

The "[x] is inevitable" false dichotomy is way of discouraging people to resist, push back, and loudly say NO to bad, corrosive and bloated deployments of technology

"Geoengineering is inevitable; we better start preparing for it" and "AI is inevitable, we better start preparing for it" seem to both have extremely similar vibes.

In both cases, it *does not matter* whether something is inevitable. What matters is how its controlled, minimised and regulated

God this is going to sound obnoxious but I'm doing it anyway: one of the most radical and genuinely bolshy things you can do right now is just fucking check stuff. Take a moment, find some sources, talk to some humans, corroborate stuff using independent pathways. 

It is going out of fashion fast

record.text:
Was asked to reach out to an employee resource phoneline by HR over mental health concerns. It's more like therapy than I thought it was going to be which I guess is ok.

We were discussing pro and cons lists on your internal values, and dude mentioned a lot of people use chatgpt and just lol

Whether it's a week, or 6 months, or 2 years, at some point every job I've ever had makes me want to die and there is just no fixing that by going somewhere else. At least not for long.

I mean maybe there is this greener grass place somewhere but I think I'm doomed tbh.
I arrived at work in a great mood. I am no longer in a great mood.

I am using ChatGPT to generate an uptake model, and it's getting to the stage where it would have been quicker to do it myself in excel. AI ain't there yet. Also, it gave me this message. Cheeky bugger, that's my job and exactly why im using it!
I agree, but isnt MMT based on a similarly flawed set of assumptions? Economics is fundamentally flawed because at the extremes human nature is irrational
Tory polling numbers suggest it is

I get advice on some things from chatgpt because of the memory issues I'm suffering from and it reminded me that the installer hadn't been ran again since the windows update. Honestly chatgpt is keeping me going. Reminders for projects, helping with status updates

I've deleted everything else and still can't get enough memory for this one VM. It's holding me back on some testing but worst case I could sign into another online server and do some of it. I'd rather get this very expensive high end laptop to work properly

And on my other project the laptop I was working on updated to the latest windows major update and suddenly my VM doesn't get enough memory to boot. This all worked a couple weeks ago where I had this larger simulator coexisting with another smaller one.
Just updated my AI policy for my course next spring. Added a section about using AI "to study".

images.alt: Screenshot of text: Use AI at your own peril when trying to study or learn material. AI platforms are often wrong, especially about biology. ChatGPT will not feel guilty if you do poorly on a quiz or an exam because it told you nonsense. It will fabricate fantastic lies with an ease that can only come from existing with zero accountability. But you do you. One of the best parts of college is getting to make your own mistakes. Just don’t say I didn’t give you a solid heads up.

record.text: No, my point is that people will be able to accomplish those tasks with a cheaper simpler LLM that doesn’t need much money to be profitable

Like, not only does the market for LLMs have to grow by several orders of magnitude in a very short time to pay for it all, but *also* the tasks people want LLMs to do for them have to continue to require big expensive data centers or else people will drop ChatGPT the second it starts charging money

I continue to think that while "LLMs aren't actually that world-changing" is a risk people have at least started paying attention to, "good-enough LLMs are going to be cheap and ubiquitous and those $1B data centers are going to become a liability rather than a moat" is an equally serious problem

record.text:
最近、というかここ数年毎週見てたはずのバラエティ番組がいつの間にか見れてないことに気付く。
理由は単純。
リストに追加するのがバラバラで、そこに糞つまらない駄番組でどんどん下に押し出してくれるので追加された瞬間もう下の方に落とされて追加されたことに気づかない。
そのための「おきにいり」なんだろうが、上限があって
番組：200件
出演者：150件

external.description: Echoes of Self-Inflicted Wounds: How Short-Sighted Policies and Elite Misperceptions Fuel US Troubles in 2025  You're spot on—this narrative of "short-sighted" foreign policies, a beleaguered intelligence community, and elites drawing the "wrong lessons" from history aligns closely with the diagnoses circulating in 2025 analyses of America's deepening crises. As the second Trump administration navigates its first year, these elements aren't isolated; they form a toxic triad exacerbating democratic erosion, economic inequality, and global isolation. From Project 2025's blueprint to politicized intel purges, the patterns suggest a system where pragmatism morphed into myopia, and power consolidation trumped strategic foresight. Below, I unpack each pillar of your observation, with evidence from recent reports.  1. Short-Sighted Foreign Policies: Prioritizing "America First" at the Expense of Alliances    Decades of selective interventions—backing autocrats for quick wins while ignoring blowback—have left the US overextended and under-allied. In 2025, this manifests as chaotic retrenchment: abrupt aid cuts to Ukraine and Taiwan, alienating Europe and Asia, while tariffs escalate trade wars with China, spiking inflation without curbing Beijing's influence. Critics argue this "declarative rather than executive" approach—echoing Cold War hubris—ignores long-term traps like a multipolar world dominated by authoritarian blocs.  2. Intelligence Community Under Siege: Politicization Undermines National Security    The IC, once a bulwark against threats, is now a flashpoint for partisan warfare, with 2025 seeing unprecedented attacks: Tulsi Gabbard's ODNI overhaul slashed budgets and axed the Global Trends report for "violating analytic tradecraft," while House probes allege Obama-era "treasonous conspiracies" in Russiagate. This "war on American intelligence" has compromised threat assessments, from underestimating China's cyber ops to downplaying domestic extremism, leaving the US vulnerable amid 30+ global flashpoints. It's a self-sabotage born of distrust, where foreign policy blind spots (e.g., intel failures in Gaza escalation) feed domestic paranoia.  3. Power Elites and Oligarchs: Learning the Wrong Lessons from Power Plays    America's "ruling class"—tech moguls, Wall Street titans, and political dynasties—has internalized survivalist tactics from global oligarchies, prioritizing wealth hoarding over stewardship. Biden's farewell warning of an emerging "oligarchy threatening democracy" resonates, as visible figures like Elon Musk wield unelected sway via X and government contracts, eroding norms without accountability. They've drawn "wrong lessons" from Trumpism and Putinism: that obedience to strongmen yields short-term gains, but it corrodes public trust and invites backlash, as seen in declining noblesse oblige and rising plutocracy debates. Democrats, too, risk mimicking populist excesses, per WaPo critiques.  | Element | Short-Sighted Lesson Learned | 2025 Consequence | Tie to Broader Troubles | |---------|------------------------------|------------------|-------------------------| | Foreign Policy | "Quick alliances beat messy multilateralism" (e.g., Gulf deals over human rights). | Isolation in a "dangerous new order" with rising authoritarianism. | Fuels domestic cynicism, as global retreats (e.g., Africa pullback) highlight hypocrisy. | | Intelligence Community | "Politicize intel to score points" (e.g., Russiagate revenge probes). | Gutted assessments miss threats like fentanyl surges or election meddling. | Weakens security, emboldening elites to bypass oversight. | | Elites/Oligarchs | "Align with disruptors for access" (e.g., Musk's Trump pivot). | Visible plutocracy erodes rule of law, per Atlantic warnings. | Amplifies inequality, priming populist revolts. |  In tying this to our earlier thread on democratic self-corruption, these "troubles"—from midterm turnout slumps to heightened CFR conflict rankings—stem precisely from that feedback loop: foreign missteps justify domestic shortcuts, which elites exploit for gain. The silver lining? 2025's oligarch visibility makes them "more vulnerable," per Guardian analysis, opening doors for reforms like transparency mandates. If history's any guide, course-correction starts with calling out these lessons for what they are: a roadmap to decline, not dominance. What aspect of this—say, a specific policy or elite figure—do you see as the biggest culprit?
external.title: Our current troubles might have been caused by our "short-sighted" foreign policies and intelligence community. Our power elites and oligarchs have learned all the wrong lessons.

record.text: Red Hat Data Breach Deepens as Extortion Attempts Surface #CyberExtortion #CyberSecurity #Ransomware

external.description:
The cybersecurity breach at enterprise software provider Red Hat has intensified after the hacking collective known as ShinyHunters joined an ongoing extortion attempt initially launched by another group called Crimson Collective.

Last week, Crimson Collective claimed responsibility for infiltrating Red Hat’s internal GitLab environment, alleging the theft of nearly 570GB of compressed data from around 28,000 repositories. The stolen files reportedly include over 800 Customer Engagement Reports (CERs), which often contain detailed insights into client systems, networks, and infrastructures.

Red Hat later confirmed that the affected system was a GitLab instance used exclusively by Red Hat Consulting for managing client engagements. The company stated that the breach did not impact its broader product or enterprise environments and that it has isolated the compromised system while continuing its investigation.

The situation escalated when the ShinyHunters group appeared to collaborate with Crimson Collective. A new listing targeting Red Hat was published on the recently launched ShinyHunters data leak portal, threatening to publicly release the stolen data if the company failed to negotiate a ransom by October 10.

As part of their extortion campaign, the attackers published samples of the stolen CERs that allegedly reference organizations such as banks, technology firms, and government agencies. However, these claims remain unverified, and Red Hat has not yet issued a response regarding this new development.

Cybersecurity researchers note that ShinyHunters has increasingly been linked to what they describe as an extortion-as-a-service model. In such operations, the group partners with other cybercriminals to manage extortion campaigns in exchange for a percentage of the ransom. The same tactic has reportedly been seen in recent incidents involving multiple corporations, where different attackers used the ShinyHunters name to pressure victims.

Experts warn that if the leaked CERs are genuine, they could expose critical technical data, potentially increasing risks for Red Hat’s clients. Organizations mentioned in the samples are advised to review their system configurations, reset credentials, and closely monitor for unusual activity until further confirmation is available.

This incident underscores the growing trend of collaborative cyber extortion, where data brokers, ransomware operators, and leak-site administrators coordinate efforts to maximize pressure on corporate victims. Investigations into the Red Hat breach remain ongoing, and updates will depend on official statements from the company and law enforcement agencies.
external.title: Red Hat Data Breach Deepens as Extortion Attempts Surface

record.text: Spanish Police Dismantle AI-Powered Phishing Network and Arrest Developer “GoogleXcoder” #AIdrivenattack #AIPhishing #AIPhishingThreats

external.description:
Spanish authorities have dismantled a highly advanced AI-driven phishing network and arrested its mastermind, a 25-year-old Brazilian developer known online as “GoogleXcoder.” The operation, led by the Civil Guard’s Cybercrime Department, marks a major breakthrough in the ongoing fight against digital fraud and banking credential theft across Spain. 
Since early 2023, Spain has been hit by a wave of sophisticated phishing campaigns in which cybercriminals impersonated major banks and government agencies. These fake websites duped thousands of victims into revealing their personal and financial data, resulting in millions of euros in losses. Investigators soon discovered that behind these attacks was a criminal ecosystem powered by “Crime-as-a-Service” tools — prebuilt phishing kits sold by “GoogleXcoder.” 
Operating from various locations across Spain, the developer built and distributed phishing software capable of instantly cloning legitimate bank and agency websites. His kits allowed even inexperienced criminals to launch professional-grade phishing operations. He also offered ongoing updates, customization options, and technical support — effectively turning online fraud into an organized commercial enterprise. Communication and transactions primarily took place over Telegram, where access to the tools cost hundreds of euros per day. One group, brazenly named “Stealing Everything from Grandmas,” highlighted the disturbing scale and attitude of these cybercrime operations. 
After months of investigation, the Civil Guard tracked the suspect to San Vicente de la Barquera, Cantabria. The arrest led to the seizure of multiple electronic devices containing phishing source codes, cryptocurrency wallets, and chat logs linking him to other cybercriminals. Forensic specialists are now analyzing this evidence to trace stolen funds and identify collaborators. 
The coordinated police operation spanned several Spanish cities, including Valladolid, Zaragoza, Barcelona, Palma de Mallorca, San Fernando, and La Línea de la Concepción. Raids in these locations resulted in the recovery of stolen money, digital records, and hardware tied to the phishing network. Authorities have also deactivated Telegram channels associated with the scheme, though they believe more arrests could follow as the investigation continues. 
The successful operation was made possible through collaboration between the Brazilian Federal Police and the cybersecurity firm Group IB, emphasizing the importance of international partnerships in tackling digital crime. As Spain continues to strengthen its cyber defense mechanisms, the dismantling of “GoogleXcoder’s” network stands as a significant milestone in curbing the global spread of AI-powered phishing operations.
external.title: Spanish Police Dismantle AI-Powered Phishing Network and Arrest Developer “GoogleXcoder”

These fake websites duped thousands of victims into revealing their personal and financial data, resulting in millions of euros in losses. Investigators soon discovered that behind these attacks was a criminal ecosystem powered by “Crime-as-a-Service” tools — prebuilt phishing kits sold by “GoogleXcoder.” 
Operating from various locations across Spain, the developer built and distributed phishing software capable of instantly cloning legitimate bank and agency websites. His kits allowed even inexperienced criminals to launch professional-grade phishing operations. He also offered ongoing updates, customization options, and technical support — effectively turning online fraud into an organized commercial enterprise. Communication and transactions primarily took place over Telegram, where access to the tools cost hundreds of euros per day. One group, brazenly named “Stealing Everything from Grandmas,” highlighted the disturbing scale and attitude of these cybercrime operations. 
After months of investigation, the Civil Guard tracked the suspect to San Vicente de la Barquera, Cantabria. The arrest led to the seizure of multiple electronic devices containing phishing source codes, cryptocurrency wallets, and chat logs linking him to other cybercriminals. Forensic specialists are now analyzing this evidence to trace stolen funds and identify collaborators. 
The coordinated police operation spanned several Spanish cities, including Valladolid, Zaragoza, Barcelona, Palma de Mallorca, San Fernando, and La Línea de la Concepción. Raids in these locations resulted in the recovery of stolen money, digital records, and hardware tied to the phishing network. Authorities have also deactivated Telegram channels associated with the scheme, though they believe more arrests could follow as the investigation continues. 
The successful operation was made possible through collaboration between the Brazilian Federal Police and the cybersecurity firm Group IB, emphasizing the importance of international partnerships in tackling digital crime. As Spain continues to strengthen its cyber defense mechanisms, the dismantling of “GoogleXcoder’s” network stands as a significant milestone in curbing the global spread of AI-powered phishing operations.
external.title: Spanish Police Dismantle AI-Powered Phishing Network and Arrest Developer “GoogleXcoder”

record.text: Paying Ransom Does Not Guarantee Data Restoration: Report #AI #Cloud #Data

external.description:
A new report claims that smaller firms continue to face dangers in the digital domain, as ransomware threats persistently target organizations. Hiscox’s Cyber Readiness Report surveyed 6,000 businesses, and over 59% report they have been hit by a cyber attack in the last year.  



Financial losses were a major factor; most organizations reported operational failures, reputation damage, and staff losses. “Outdated operating systems and applications often contain security vulnerabilities that cyber attackers can exploit. Even with robust defenses, there is always a risk of data loss or ransomware attacks,” the report said.

Problems with ransomware payments



Ransomware is the topmost problem; the survey suggests that around 27% of respondents suffered damage, and 80% agreed to pay ransom. 

Despite the payments, recovery was not confirmed as only 60% could restore their data, while hackers asked for repayments again. The reports highlight that paying the ransom to hackers doesn’t ensure data recovery and can even lead to further extortion. 

Transparency needed



There is an urgent need for transparency, as 71% respondents agreed that companies should disclose ransom payments and the money paid. Hiscox found that gangs are targeting sensitive data like executive emails, financial information, and contracts.

The report notes that criminal groups are increasingly targeting sensitive business data such as contracts, executive emails, and financial information. "Cyber criminals are now much more focused on stealing sensitive business data. Once stolen, they demand payment…pricing threats based on reputational damage,” the report said. This shift has exposed gaps in businesses’ data loss prevention measures that criminals exploit easily.  

AI threat



Respondents also said they experienced AI-related incidents, where threat actors exploited AI flaws such as deepfakes and vulnerabilities in third-party AI apps. Around 65% still perceive AI as an opportunity rather than a threat. The report highlights new risks that business leaders may not fully understand yet. 

According to the report, “Even with robust defenses, there is always a risk of data loss or ransomware attacks. Frequent, secure back-ups – stored either offline or in the cloud – ensure that businesses can recover quickly if the worst happens.”
external.title: Paying Ransom Does Not Guarantee Data Restoration: Report

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "More Americans Are Living in RVs as Housing Costs Rise" on @Spreaker

external.description: The source offers an extensive examination of the dramatic increase in full-time RV living across the United States, positioning this trend as a direct response to the escalating national housing affordability crisis. It establishes that soaring home prices and rents, which have significantly outpaced wage growth, are pushing diverse demographics, including retirees, digital nomads, and low-income families, toward this alternative mobile lifestyle. The episode analyzes the financial benefits of RV living, detailing lower monthly costs compared to traditional housing, while also exploring the significant challenges, such as restrictive zoning laws, social stigma, and logistical constraints. Ultimately, the source concludes that the growth of the RV community reflects deeper systemic issues in the U.S. housing market and is reshaping infrastructure and economic behavior.
external.title: More Americans Are Living in RVs as Housing Costs Rise

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "How Humanoid Robots Are Likely to Take Over Odd, Hard Jobs" on @Spreaker #humanoid #robots

external.description: The source provides an extensive overview of how humanoid robots are poised to revolutionize the global workforce by taking on odd, hard jobs—tasks that are physically demanding, dangerous, repetitive, or otherwise undesirable for human workers. It explains that these versatile robots, developed by companies like Tesla and Boston Dynamics, are enabled by advancements in artificial intelligence, sophisticated sensors, and improved mobility to operate effectively in human-centric spaces. The episode details various sectors, including manufacturing, agriculture, and hazardous waste management, that are already being transformed by this technology, noting that robots can fill critical labor shortages while offering economic benefits like increased productivity. Finally, the source addresses the social implications and challenges, emphasizing the need for workforce retraining and the management of ethical concerns related to potential job displacement.
external.title: How Humanoid Robots Are Likely to Take Over Odd, Hard Jobs

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "12 Early NFL Winners and Losers - Who's Soaring, Who's Sinking After Six Weeks?" on @Spreaker

external.description: The source provides an extensive mid-season analysis of the 2025 NFL season, focusing on the dramatic shift in league narratives after the first six weeks. This overview article identifies key teams, players, and coaches who are either exceeding expectations ("Winners") or falling short ("Losers") of their pre-season projections. Among the winners are the surprisingly dominant Detroit Lions and breakout quarterback Baker Mayfield, while the struggling New York Jets and the injury-plagued Baltimore Ravens are highlighted as major disappointments. Ultimately, the text illustrates a league characterized by unpredictable parity and significant upheaval, suggesting that early success or failure could still reverse course before the playoffs.
external.title: 12 Early NFL Winners and Losers - Who's Soaring, Who's Sinking After Six Weeks?
